Rooting can be done with simple vegetables—like onions and radish—by sticking the root or leafy portion into water for a few days.

I’m pretty sure I figured out what happened. 2.6K comments in, I haven’t read to see if someone else said the same thing or not. Plants need air pressure to drive water into them through their roots. That’s why the vacuum jar turned out the worst. In the sealed carbon dioxide jar, the plants eat the air and thus probably created a partial vacuum, thus partially matching the vacuum experiment. In the oxygen jar, less air gets eaten and the pressure maintains at high enough levels to keep pushing the water into the roots. To test this, you could pressurize some jars with different gases, maybe with balloons to see how the pressure changes if the balloons shrink. Also, if the pressure is high, then maybe the plants will thrive more. The plants might not need carbon dioxide to maintain, but I’m not sure if they can harness the energy of light without it, so in a prolonged experiment with constant air pressure, I would expect carbon dioxide to win, provided the pressure is from a constant supply.

Plants can rely on respiration quite well when they have little to no light but plenty of oxygen, at least for a while. With a lack of adequate light, carbon dioxide is not much use to a plant. Chlorophyll relies on UV light to provide the energy to break CO2 down. As that glass probably isn't particularly UV-permeable (and direct sunlight could boil the jar) a UV lamp might help. Without O2 to support respiration, and without the energy needed to process CO2 (i.e. UV light), the atmosphere is just as toxic to the plant as it would be to you.

The O2 jar will eventually be full of CO2 as the plant respires. Without adequate light, this would end up killing the plant too.

With a nice big jar and plenty of light, you could start with O2 and watch the plant thrive! Theoretically, it will perpetually recycle between O2 and CO2 (and there is a real world sealed bottle garden that has reportedly thrived for decades without additional water).

What I believe to have happened was the jar with the CO2, killed off all of the microbes and CO2 producing organism within the environment.  Soil contains hundreds of millions of microbes per cubic inch and they play a huge factor in the health of the ecosystem.  Therefore, once the plant had used up all the CO2 within the closed system, none was being produced and it slowly starved.  Although people are mentioning that photo respiration was the reason the plant survived, it is not an efficient enough process to maintain the plant over the course of a week.  Plants do not fulfill the full cycle of cell reps like humans do, and therefore it’s oxygen consuming phase is very inefficient.  The oxygen produced as a product of photosynthesis would have also allowed the plant to carry out photo respiration in the CO2 jar, which obviously did not nurture the plant enough.  The CO2 would have also been heavier than the trace amounts of oxygen in the CO2 jar and sank to the bottom, essentially creating a buffer from the oxygen and suffocating. When you make a closed system terrarium, the plant does not survive because of the initial CO2 deposits, but rather the relationship with the living, oxygen producing microorganisms that live in the soil.  Just a thought, thanks for reading my lab report.

Is oxygen needed for growing plants? Yes, it is. Plants need oxygen to survive, and plant cells are constantly using oxygen. Under certain circumstances, plant cells need to take in more oxygen from the air than they generate themselves. So, if plants generate oxygen through photosynthesis, why do plants need oxygen? The reason is that plants respire, too, just like animals. Respiration doesn’t just mean “breathing.” It is a process that all living things use to release energy for use in their cells. Respiration in plants is like photosynthesis run backwards: instead of capturing energy by manufacturing sugars and releasing oxygen, cells release energy for their own use by breaking down sugars and using up oxygen.

Here's a factor you may not have thought about, Nate: There are other living things in the soil besides just the plant, like microorganisms. Some of those things may have a symbiotic relationship with the plants. They may also rely on oxygen to survive. It's possible strongly oxygenating the atmosphere of the O2 jar made those creatures thrive, which in turn made the plant thrive. Conversely, filling the sealed CO2 jar may have made those do badly, which led to the plant doing poorly. The open jar still had access to atmosphere so likely despite the CO2 doses such organisms might still be able to survive.

For those pondering the one in the vacuum. Plants utilize water to do the job our blood does. At the leaves there are very small openings just large enough for water molecules to evaporate from. This causes a negative pressure (possible in liquids) that pulls water up the plant bringing sugars and minerals up to the leaves. When you put it into a vacuum the water in the soil undergo a phase change into a gas. So the jar was actually filled with water vapor (Hence the water droplets on the inside of the jar) because of this and the conditions it was then impossible for water to evaporate from the leaves and 'pump' up sugars and nutrients since the water vapor atmosphere within was already at its maximum pressure.

Plants "breathe" the same way as humans. Regular respiration requires oxygen and sugar. Anaerobic respiration in humans produce lactic acid and in plants produce alcohol. Photosynthesis is a different reaction. It's a method plants use to produce sugar and that releases oxygen. The roots of a plant drawn in water and nutrients which are pulled up to the rest of the plant via xylem, while the food produced will be transported by the phloem. Plants do not have a heart to pump fluids through them, so transpiration is how the pull the water and nutrients up. By allowing the underside of leaves to release water, the water from the roots is drawn up.
This is all basic plant biology and the information is freely available to anyone.

I recommend growing basil and tomatoes together. They both are very forgiving when it comes to growing them in pots. Use a 5 gallon bucket for the tomatoes and paint the buckets black. Having researched a bit of hydroponics and aeroponics,
1) Plants definitely need oxygen and that’s one of the reasons aeroponics and hydroponics with aeration into the nutrient solution works as effectively as it does: oxygen availability to the roots.
2) Earth’s base atmosphere is ~20% oxygen whereas CO2 exists in very small amounts relatively.
3) When you’re smelling the sealed jars, you’re not smelling only your test basil plant but any and all soil bacteria that was also trapped into the environment with the plant during your test period. Aerobic bacteria growth vs anaerobic bacteria growth (or suppression/absence) are affected by the sealed environments as well.
(Also, sealing and temp affects things like humidity, which definitely affects plant growth and would be much more difficult to control for.)

The mould on your open control is called botrytis. It's a greyish mould caused, normally by dampness.
Basil is actually very prone to it. My family owned a garden centre in the Uk and overwinter or a particularly wet and cold summer we'd lose a lot of our basil plant to it. It's caused by damp air and cold or watering late in the day when it's cold overnight. The best way to prevent it is to water the plant's first thing in the morning so they have all day to dry off and keep them somewhere warmer overnight (if memory serves me correct above 10°C.)

I don't think the experiment produced reliable results because of the way it was conducted. My suggestion:
Wash and sterilize jars using the same disinfectants that are used by home winemakers.
Moisten sterilized topsoil.
Weigh portions of topsoil that will amount to 2" in each jar.
Mix grass seed into moistened sterilized topsoil.
Weigh a portion of the grass seed mix into each jar to make a thin layer on top of the topsoil that is already in there.
Allow the grass to grow to a height of 1".
Except for the vacuum jar, hang a thin wire (paperclip?) over the edge of each jar to prevent a seal from forming. Put a lid on each jar.
Put the jars, one at a time, into the vacuum chamber and remove the air.
Refill the chamber with the CO2, O2, or air. (An unsealed jar is not a valid control because it was not treated exactly the same as the treatment jars.)
Remove the paperclip and seal each jar without admitting air.
Observe as the grass grows.

Because it would be easy to do, not because you expect healthy grass, you might try a treatment jar filled with methane, propane or butane.

I have a degree in plant science and I can shed some light on why the CO2 plant died and the Oxygen plant did just fine. Basically plants still need oxygen. Yes plants use CO2 + Sunlight to make sugars to store the energy of the sun for later and oxygen is a by product here. The important part is that in order to release and harness the energy stored in the sugar they need to use oxygen in the process, creating water and CO2 again. So it's theoretically a closed loop, but in actuality the plant needs both Water and Oxygen and CO2 to be supplied to it in order to thrive in the long run. Reason being that all the pieces need to come together at the right time, all of them need to be plentiful enough to randomly interact in the chaotic mess that is the life of a cell.
It's a fine tuned process that has been evolved over millions or billions of years so it is especially adapted to deal with the concentrations similar to those found in nature. In nature O2 makes up ~20% of the atmosphere where as CO2 is 410 parts per million or 0.041% so the plant is going to be a lot more sensitive to the oxygen level going to 0 than the CO2.
Another way to think about it is taking away the CO2 stops the plant from storing new energy while taking away all the O2 takes away its ability to release any of its stored energy so it doesn't matter how much more energy it can store with all that CO2 available.
Final point here, the marginal amount of CO2 released in the process of the plant breaking down its sugars would be much more significant to the plant because it is used to such low levels. Comparatively the marginal amount of O2 released in photosynthesis is going to seem like nothing when the plant is used to a 20% O2 atmosphere.

The plant that survived in O2 flourished while the carbon dioxide one wilted was because while plants do need CO2 in order to produce sugars, they still have mitochondria that transform sugar into ATP, and the mitochondria still need O2 to perform that task. That coupled with its food stores and extremely low metabolism, a result of it being a plant, allowed the plant's own production of CO2 to match its intake needed for photosynthesis.

"Plants breathing" CO2 triggered me as a microbiologist. Plants do not perform the act of breathing but they do respire (require respiration.) Because, just like us, they need oxygen to oxidize carbohydrates (which they synthesize through photosynthesis using CO2). So although they need CO2 to eat, they need O2 "to breathe". And just because they can produce more O2 from CO2 overall people tend to think they only consume CO2.

As a side note, im not sure if plants can absorb sugars (in sufficient amounts) through their roots. If so, that would theretically make CO2 completely optional for plants. Unless they require it to regulate their physiological pH and would not produce enough CO2 themselves to do that.

Putting a plant in a jar does increase the chances of it getting moldy or rotten - the jar walls reduce airflow, so water is slower to evaporate off the areas of the plant which shouldn't be wet (like the leaves) which allows more time for mold spores to develop. Put a lid on it and the chances go way up that something bad will happen. If the leaves are big enough to be pressing up against the walls of the jar, same deal - reduced ability to evaporate any moisture, higher chance of rot.

Even when incubating seeds in an enclosed environment you still don't make them that enclosed - you generally give them multiple times more head room than the volume of soil/growing medium used.

I have an explanation for the co2 and o2 jars:

for the CO2 jar :even though plants do produce more oxygen and absorb carvon dioxide to make glucose plants also NEED oxygen as like us they do cellular respiration. Since there was not enough oxygen for them to essentially breathe, the cells in the plant died. And I think that bcos the cells died, the chlorophyll in the cells which gives plants the green colour died and it got decoloured.

For the oxgen container: even though there was no carbon dioxide for the plants to absorb and make glucose which is essentially their food, plants actually store their excess glucose in the stems and other parts of the plant in the form of starch(edit) so since it still had oxygen to breathe the cells did not die and the plant was living on its food storage from the glucose it had produced prior to the experiment

TLDR: CO2 is for food and O2 is for breathing and like humans, plants can survive longer without food than without breath.

Too much water, probably fungus gnats, and fungal spores from the air either in the lab or from where you got them could be contributing factors to the health of plants.
The pure CO2 one suffocated the roots of the plant and the aerobic bacteria and fungi, acidified the soil, and decreased the ability of the plant to use water. The pure O2 allows the roots to breathe and gave the cells enough fuel for respiration (burning stored energy, like animal cells) which may temporarily make up for the lack of photosynthesis, plants are massive carbohydrate/sugar stores afterall. But the pure O2 is probably more reliably explained by creating an atmosphere that's great for the roots and the aerobic bacteria and fungi present in the soil, which then produce carbon dioxide and other nutrients for the plant to use to grow.
